channel.title: Ubuntu 10.04 broke bluetooth
channel.description:
:(
I can't use my desktop until I can get my hands on a non-bluetooth mouse. With that said, how difficult is it going to be to fix this? Obviously it's the first problem I've ran into.

item.title: Ubuntu 10.04 broke bluetooth
item.dc:creator: @yakman yakman
item.description:
@yakman wrote:

I’ve recently gotten to know gvim and its pretty hot.
Good if you’re learning I think, you can use the vim keybindings or click the menus if you forgot the shortcut.

Read full topic

item.title: Ubuntu 10.04 broke bluetooth
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

Mopman and I have had this discussion on IRC before. I agree nano would probably be rather painful to program in, except for small changes, and, as Mopman said, is much better suited for configuration file changes. Vi[m] or emacs would probably be better for programming, but then I tend to use an X text editor like kate when doing that stuff, or a full-blown IDE.

Read full topic

item.title: Ubuntu 10.04 broke bluetooth
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

Just to balance out the vi[m] bashing, it really is kinda awesome when you get to know it. A bit like c|p, only retarded at first glance.

Also, there is dvorak compatibility stuff available (in vim, not vi, though who uses vi these days). No idea how good it is though, I use qwerty.

Read full topic

item.title: Ubuntu 10.04 broke bluetooth
item.dc:creator: @lothy Lothy
item.description:
@lothy wrote:

Thanks for the tip – so nano from now on. I do agree with you, vi is awful.

On the bright side, mouse and keyboard now work and sound has been restored too. Hopefully that’s the last of any defects that are going to affect me personally.

Read full topic

item.title: Ubuntu 10.04 broke bluetooth
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

Lothy:

I see. I used the ‘vi’ command. What is vi meant to do?

It’s also a text editor, but that is more Mopman’s territory, it uses a combination of horrible shortcuts to get things done that you need to memorize, and also are painful to do using a dvorak layout. So I just stick with nano.

Read full topic

item.title: Ubuntu 10.04 broke bluetooth

item.title: Ubuntu 10.04 broke bluetooth
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

As to modifying a file via the terminal, I love to use ‘nano’, obviously if it is a file you need root permissions to modify you type ‘sudo nano’, so to open a specific file, something like ‘sudo nano /etc/X11/xorg.conf’ etc etc. All the shortcuts you need to save, close etc are at the bottom of the screen.

As to:
https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/bluez/+bug/550288/comments/10
It looks as if the driver in the newer linux kernel changed the name of a module or filename from ‘hiddev*’ to ‘hidraw*’, and ubuntu (or maybe debian) didn’t update their udev rules to reflect this change. That is what you did and now it works.

Read full topic

item.title: Ubuntu 10.04 broke bluetooth
item.dc:creator: @lothy Lothy
item.description:
@lothy wrote:

Thanks Mopman and Mopar (mostly Mopman, though :P).

Try as I might, I couldn’t for the life of me actually figure out how to modify a file inside of the terminal (I could open/view it, but it wouldn’t let me change it and when I typed it would delete what was already there, as if I had bumped the insert key).
With that said, I hijacked a mouse from another computer, opened abiword as a root user from bash and then modified the file there.

Obviously I’m a bit of a noob, but if it works.

EDIT: Also, for the record I didn’t take all of yesterday and today to figure it out (which the time between posts might suggest XD). I actually decided to bust out Ocarina of Time yesterday to play through again; I’ve gotten about half of the golden skulltalas, and so far finished the forest and fire temples.

Also, can either of you tell me why the solution that Mopman linked to works?

Read full topic

item.title: Ubuntu 10.04 broke bluetooth
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

If you log in, alt+f2 will let you type in a command to run. Otherwise you can go to a real terminal as explained above.

I’ve never had any bluetooth accesories so I don’t have any experiance with them on any OS.

Read full topic

item.title: Ubuntu 10.04 broke bluetooth
item.dc:creator: @lothy Lothy
item.description:
@lothy wrote:

[me=Lothy]shrugs[/me]

I could log in as per usual by hitting the space bar in place of a mouse click. But winkey+r doesn’t do anything. I’m afraid I don’t actually know how to get into the terminal without using mouse clicks. I didn’t consider checking earlier, either, so it won’t get fixed until tomorrow.

Read full topic

item.description:
@xx_matty_xx wrote:

On mine, I can use the num pad keys with arrows on them to move the mouse pointer. I can’t remember if I changed a setting for that though, but you could always try it.

There might be a command to turn this feature on!
